channel.title: Creating own cover art- software, methods?
channel.description:
Hey guys, I really like the cover art ppl are creating themselves, like @aUstin_Haga, @Produk , and @MR_ANDERSON , and I was wondering if you guys or anyone else would share what you use to create your own art as I am considering making my own too.(if you don't mind ppl knowing. If you want it secret, don't tell then!)
Thank you all!

item.title: Creating own cover art- software, methods?
item.dc:creator: AnirudhKhanna
item.description:
Canva (online), Phonto (app)

I use those two, they make good art

item.title: Creating own cover art- software, methods?
item.dc:creator: crystldawnmusic
item.description:
Here‚Äôs my process:

  • First, I visit unsplash.com and download a royalty-free photo to use. They‚Äôve got some super high-quality pictures. (I hope to use pictures that I take one day, but not yet.)
  • After that, I go to Trigraphy (iOS) and blend it with some snazzy modern-art effects.
  • I finish it off with Over (also iOS) by adding a track name in one of their amazing fonts.
  • Occasionally, I will also add my logo.

Hope this was helpful!

Read full topic
item.source: Creating own cover art- software, methods?

item.title: Creating own cover art- software, methods?
item.dc:creator: Arimyth
item.description:
I‚Äôd recommend investing in a decent art program, as it has many uses outside of creating cover art. Here are a few recommendations:

  • Affinity Designer (~$48) Like a better version of photoshop. A bit of a learning curve but if you invest about 15 minutes into it you can easily get the hang of making professional album art among countless other things.

  • Pixelmator (~$20) Not as full featured as Affinity Designer but you can do some nice things with it for less than half the price, including well designed album art.

  • Trigraphy (~$25 for a subscription) Essentially just adds filters to your photos. I wouldn‚Äôt recommend it as you can‚Äôt really go anywhere beyond photo editing.

  • Canva (Free for most uses) I used to use this service but stopped because of the limitations. You may as well invest in real software if you‚Äôre willing to pay the fee to remove those limitations.

I wouldn‚Äôt recommend photoshop unless you plan on getting into digital design beyond cover art as it has a very high price tag and a somewhat steep learning curve to it. Paint.NET is an okay choice as well but is windows exclusive.

(For what it‚Äôs worth, I do all my designing including cover art in Affinity Designer currently. I‚Äôd definitely recommend it.)

Read full topic
item.source: Creating own cover art- software, methods?

If you‚Äôre going for something super crazy and high quality (and 3D) you can get something like C4D.
